Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Soon after the report "Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education was published by AAAS (2009), the American Society for Microbiology (ASM) convened a committee to create a document outlining the core concepts that any student in a microbiology course should learn. With the participation of hundreds of microbiology faculty across the country, the ASM published the ASM Curriculum Guidelines for Undergraduate Microbiology (Merkel et al., 2012) - a comprehensive set of six core concepts and 27 fundamental statements based on Vision and Change. College instructors often struggle to determine if altering teaching methods actually leads to increased student learning. This is where the development of concept inventories can be helpful. Concept inventories are assessments that specifically address core concepts in a particular discipline. They are typically multiple choice instruments that use commonly held misconceptions as distractors. In support of innovation in undergraduate biology education, the American Society for Microbiology (ASM) established three committees to construct, review, validate and disseminate two different concept inventories. One concept inventory focuses on core microbiology concepts taught in general microbiology for microbiology majors. The second concept inventory is focused on health sciences general microbiology concepts. The third committee's charge is the independent review of both of the concept inventories.

Developing and validating a concept inventory is time intensive and requires a great deal of collaboration among faculty experts. This ASM Microbiology Concept Inventory Conference is bringing together these three teams now that they have completed their initial work (which has taken place using virtual meeting formats whenever there has been a need to meet). The project is nearing the stage of development where face-to-face discussion and planning are necessary. The two-day conference will allow a focused review of the work that has been completed. At this conference, researchers will present and discuss the preliminary data from the formal review as well as the initial statistical analysis from the early in-class trials for both concept inventories. Conference attendees will review each concept inventory for potential gaps and write new questions as needed to fill those gaps. Once completed, these concept inventories will be useful tools that will be available to hundreds of microbiology faculty teaching tens of thousands of microbiology students. Concept inventories that can accurately and reliably measure student learning gains can be widely used by faculty teaching microbiology. Lastly, the concept inventory teams will discuss and determine the best mechanism to both store and disseminate the completed concept inventories once they are validated after statistical analysis of each question after the concept inventories have been used on a larger, nationwide scale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The U.S. will need thousands of new STEM-trained workers in the next two decades. Some of these workers are in our classrooms right now and some college instructors are actively engaging them in the science and process of microbiological inquiry, employing case studies, flipped classrooms, team-based learning and other innovative techniques. Other instructors take a traditional lecture approach. Without a means to accurately measure student learning of the fundamental concepts in microbiology as described by the American Society for Microbiology (ASM) in the community-developed, peer-reviewed Curriculum Guidelines for Undergraduate Microbiology it is difficult to know which, if any of these teaching methods foster student learning. A concept inventory is a set of questions that have been tested in multiple settings with various student and faculty groups to verify that they both measure expert-like thinking (validity) and work in a similar fashion when widely used (reliability).

The Microbiology Concept Inventory Conference was a critical step to the creation of both the Microbiology Concept Inventory (MCI) and Microbiology Health Sciences Concept Inventory (MHSCI). This conference enabled the statistician to meet with the researchers writing, reviewing and administering the development versions of the concept inventories. It allowed the conference participants to evaluate each question individually based on initial statistical data and student feedback. This led to the replacement of questions in both the MCI and MHSCI. This conference also provided an opportunity to discuss the administration and testing of the second version of both concept inventories. In the months after this conference, data from microbiology courses all over the country were gathered and subjected to rigorous statistical analysis to ensure the validity and reliability of both concept inventories.

Both concept inventories are valuable tools that enable a wide variety of stakeholders in undergraduate education to measure student learning gains. Educators teaching general microbiology and health sciences microbiology now have a means to identify common student misconceptions and address these directly in class. If used at the start of a course, taking either concept inventory may inform students and teachers of students’ strengths and weaknesses which will lead to a more customized course experience, with instructors tailoring learning activities to each cohort’s needs.

These new tools were valuable enough to generate multiple presentations in both 2016 and 2017. Members of the development team introduced each of the concept inventories at national meetings (ASM Microbe and the ASM Conference for Undergraduate Educators; ASMCUE) in 2016. There will be a poster presentation on the common misconceptions revealed by the MCI and a session dedicated to reporting the uses of the MCI and MHSCI at the 2017 ASMCUE national meeting. This project also resulted in the submission and forthcoming publication of three separate research articles.

In short, by funding the Microbiology Concept Inventories Conference, the National Science Foundation has enabled our researchers to create, validate and publish two new tools that will facilitate further research on how to best teach microbiology for years to come.
